Articles.Content: So umm... I've kind of been doing stuff I probably shouldn't be doing with Hyper Edit, and I was going at speeds so high in my spacecraft that I actually ended up reaching the Ps and eventually 16309E before my game crashed. But before it crashed, as my ship was cruising along I started to hear this high pitched creepy beeping sound that got faster and faster very quickly and constantly changed tones. This is not a complaint, I was just wondering, was that programed into the game to tell people to back the !@#$ off if they screwed around too much, or am I breaking the game?
You are either making up a story or you broke your game.
It's not broken...yet...I tried closing it and opening it again and it all works fine, though I'm sure trying it again would be a bad idea. I'm not making it up either.

Hey you know once when i was using hyper edit i was using the constant forcer thing. and i set it to 1234532431 (something around there) and i was just gone from the system, and i just head this beeping too...
Are you orbiting Duna?

Are you orbiting Duna?

no, he said he was long gone out of the solar system.

Are you orbiting Duna?
You can't hear the Duna signals in orbit anyway.

If you don't want to see spoilers about the game's easter eggs, you may not want to watch this, but did it sound like

?

Is it anything like the sound you get if you move the camera in front of a craft that's moving through water reasonably quickly? You can hear this by putting a jet engine on one or two jet fuel tanks, putting a rectangular wing peice on each side of that, and throttling up in the ocean, if you haven't already heard it.

I've heard this happen to someone before. I guess the game just got confused and started playing- *signal lost*.

Edited July 3, 2013 by RocketPilot573

I've just had a go at reaching several times the speed of light using Hyperedit to try this and I didn't find any beeping. I did crash the game though and get other crafts travelling at NaN m/s.

Did you check for back ground applications?
Wait, so you intentionally glitched the game and then became confused when your computer was giving weird sensory output?

If you don't want to see spoilers about the game's easter eggs, you may not want to watch this, but did it sound like
?

Actually, yes, but I was WAY far out of the solar system, going at over 200 million m/s
I'll try to get a video of it in here, if I can do it again and figure out how to post it.
Its the krakens call...or more likely and audio bug.
Alright, here's a link to the video I just uploaded. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TtK5ZGop2fI
That is an sstv signal probably the duna one

Maybe your were going so fast... that you were... everywhere...

hence why you heard the Duna signal.

It could be an issue with the whole floating point system they have, it moves the universe around the ship at high speeds.

As FITorion said, you were probably everywhere at once. Or so close (or so far!) that it makes no difference. I wonder how high speeds would affect crafts that are more than one part if you EVA?
Can someone decode it just incase?

It could be an issue with the whole floating point system they have, it moves the universe around the ship at high speeds.

As FITorion said, you were probably everywhere at once. Or so close (or so far!) that it makes no difference. I wonder how high speeds would affect crafts that are more than one part if you EVA?

I actually went back and tried that with a bigger ship and tried EVA, surprisingly nothing really happens. The ship stays intact and the Kerbal just floats around and moves in whatever direction I move him. However, if it gets to the point where my speed suddenly becomes 0, hitting EVA breaks the universe. Or, at least that's what happened with me.

Interesting find, it does sound exactly like the Duna SSTV signal that trbinsc posted earlier in this thread.

I suspect it's just a game glitch, albeit an unusual one.
It's definitely an SSTV signal but I can't get an image out of it. Perhaps malformed Duna SSTV signal?
Yea, that's the Duna SSTV.

When you hear an SSTV, you can tell its one, but if the images look alike, you cant differenciate both by ear. Maybe its not the Duna SSTV but another of the same kind. We should get a proper record of the signal, and in full lengh if possible. Then we will be able to decode it and we will know. Too bad i dont have hyper edit. But somebody can do it
